links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{Poem infobox | title=Visio de Doworst | other names=''Doworst'',
''Do Worst'',
''Visio Petri Aratoris de Doworst'',
''Incipit Visio Petri Aratoris de Doworst'' | written=Around [[1933]] | revised=Summer, [[1953]] | published=''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=Non-legendarium poetry }} '''''Visio de Doworst''''' is a humorous poem that was written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in a medieval style reminiscent of ''[[Wikipedia:Piers Plowman|Piers Plowman]]''.{{CG|RG}}, p. 214 == First stanza == In a summer season when sultry was the sun with lourdains and lubbers I lounged in a hall, and wood in his wits was each wight as meseemed: on his head was a hat as hard as a board, on his neck was there knotted a noose all of white with big bow and broad as a butterfly's wings. Most of that meiny had on mantles of stuff, shrouds short as shrift and shapeless as sacks that never covered their tails nor their touts either. The clamour of that company was the cackle of hens, till a bell rang brazenly —- that abated their noise!{{CP|139}} == Background == [[File:J.R.R. Tolkien - Doworst (manuscript).jpg|thumb|Tolkien's decorated manuscript.]] The earliest surviving manuscript, entitled both '''''Doworst''''' and '''''Visio Petri Aratoris de Doworst''''', was [[Letter to R.W. Chambers|given]] by Tolkien to [[R.W. Chambers]] as a [[Christmas]] gift{{CG|2II}}, entry "Chambers, Raymond Wilson" on December 21 of [[1933]]. After the death of Chambers in [[1942]], the decorated manuscript containing the poem came into the possession of his secretary, Winifred Husband. In [[1957]], upon her retirement, Husband gave the manuscript to Arthur Brown, who later became the Professor of English at [[Wikipedia:Monash University|Monash University]] in Australia. While the manuscript was later lost upon Brown's death in [[1979]], parts of the poem and its background were printed as "'''''Do Worst'''''" in "Fantasy that! — a Tolkien original", an article published in July of [[1975]] within the third issue of the ''[[Monash Review 3 (1975)|Monash Review]]''. The article describes the poem's background and contains a transcription of a letter from Tolkien to R.W. Chambers.{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://www.tolkienguide.com/modules/newbb/viewtopic.php?topic_id=1805&forum=9&post_id=9618#forumpost9618|articlename=Doworst in 'Monash Review'|dated=|website=Guide|accessed=27 February 2012}} In the summer of [[1978]], the first nineteen lines of the poem were printed as "'''''Doworst'''''" in an article on the third page of [[A Elbereth Gilthoniel! 1, no. 2|''A Elbereth Gilthoniel!'' 1, no. 2]], an issue of ''A Elbereth Gilthoniel!'', a newsletter published by The Fellowship of Middle Earth, a Tolkien fan-group at Monash University.[[Douglas A. Anderson]], "R. W. Chambers and ''The Hobbit''", in ''Tolkien Studies'', Vol. III, p. 144"[http://www.tolkienbooks.net/php/details.php?reference=63510 A Elbereth Gilthoniel. 1978]" on tolkienbooks.net"[http://www.tolkienguide.com/modules/wiwimod/index.php?page=AElbereth2-78 A Elbereth Gilthoniel! #2 (1978)]" on tolkienguide.com, July 7, 2011 The exact month and day of the issue’s publication is not known, but it was likely published either between June and July, or between May and August."[http://libus.csd.mu.edu/record=b2244689 A elbereth gilthoniel! (microform)]" on [http://libus.csd.mu.edu/ Marquette University Libraries Online Catalog] Though the original manuscript was lost, Tolkien made another manuscript entitled '''''Incipit Visio Petri Aratoris de Doworst''''', which he gave to [[C.S. Lewis]]. After Lewis's death in [[1963]], the manuscript came into Walter Hooper's possession and ended up in the Bodleian Library after Hooper's death. In the summer of [[1953]], Tolkien revised the poem, shortening it significantly, and gave a calligraphic{{CG|2II}}, entry "Lea, Kathleen Marguerite" copy of it to Kathleen Lea, who sent him a letter of thanks and some [[Wikipedia:Sherry|sherry]] on [[5 August]]. This version was entitled ''Visio de Doworst''. {{references}} {{poems}} [[Category:Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien]] [[Category:Unpublished material]]
